commits.message: get rid of old backend files

payload.description: ĐOor opens doors at events that are anchored on the Ethereum blockchain. Bouncers scan your dynamic QR code to verify that you're a registered ticket owner.

commits.message: Door contracts restructured.Door Meetups and Door Events have now the same function basis.
Merge branch 'niels-dev' of github.com:d0or/dOor into niels-dev

Door contracts restructured.
Door Meetups and Door Events have now the same function basis.

Basic door functionalities have been outsourced.
Further files must be adapted.

pull_request.title: door event naming
pull_request.body:
dropped unnecessary comments
changed naming for most of the things

commits.message:
door event naming

dropped all comments

renamed things in Door "manager"

why is it called a "manager" anyway? imo the term "factory" perfectly describes what it's going to do.

Comments reviewed.
Some changes accepted, some reverted.

comment.body:
at the moment the DoorEvent.sol is not emitting a "door creation" event. You think we do not need that?
DoorEvent.sol is just emitting an event called "LogDoorEventTicketSold(msg.sender)" where we can listen on ("ticket counter" or "X tickets sold - hurry up")

comment.body:
>     * I removed all "unnecessary" comments according to https://blog.usejournal.com/stop-writing-code-comments-28fef5272752 (which is just the substrate of 20 years of coding style)
> 
>     * renamed many things

unnecessary comments?
sometimes, maybe. After one month I dont even remember the logic within my code so am more than happy to have a few breadcrumbs between the lines..
I will look into the article.

comment.body: question is -> if the factory already emits these events... why should the door contract be able to do so? because it should be possible that someone spawns a door without using the factory? then you don't need to emit these events from the factory but solely can trust the spawned door contracts to emit them...

comment.body: since we're talking about "prices" here, I think it's a good thing consistently refer to everyhing as a "ticket".
